Origins: In November 2014, a scam promising a free BMW 435i started circulating on Facebook.
Description: The fraudulent offer was first posted to the BMW ///M Power Facebook Page (no affiliation to the car company) on 12 November 2014. The message instructed users to like, comment, and share the post in order to win a free car: This is a common strategy used in social media scams. Recent offers for fake Costco , Kroger and Amazon gift cards all employed similar tactics in order to spread their message quickly across the internet. The free BMW giveaway post was shared by more than a half million people in just a few days. In fact, it became so popular that BMW (the real BMW) stepped in to tell its customers it was fake:
Example: [Collected via e-mail, November 2014] "BMW ///M POWER's photos are being advertised on Facebook as a giveaway, but never seem to see any winners posted. Is it a fake or for real."
Claim: BMW is giving away free cars on Facebook.
